newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan won't seek Iraq oil-for-food crude.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan won't seek Iraq oil-for-food crude.

text.p: Taiwan's oil monopoly is no longer seeking to buy Iraqi crude under a stalled U.N. oil-for-food scheme, but it said on Wednesday that Beijing -- not Baghdad -- was the reason.
"Chinese Petroleum has given up plans to buy Iraqi oil through the United Nations' oil-for-food programme," company spokesman Fang Yi-shan told Reuters.

Fang said the decision was not caused by the apparent collapse of the scheme following renewed U.S. military strikes on Iraq, but rather reflected political hurdles Taiwan faces in its relations with China.
The state-owned oil monopoly backed off after it discovered how much clout China was wielding in the U.N. Security Council's sanctions committee on Iraq, Fang said.
"We know that China would not let Taiwan get Iraq's oil through the U.N., so Chinese Petroleum quit considering the oil-for-food programme," Fang said.

Fang said China, one of five veto-holding permanent members of the Security Council, had great influence in the management of the oil-for-food programme because it occupied the executive secretariat of a council panel overseeing it.
Iraq nevertheless remains on Chinese Petroleum's list of potential oil suppliers.
"We are still interested to have more oil supply sources, including Iraq," Fang said.
In June, Chinese Petroleum disclosed that it was in talks with Iraq over possible crude purchases under the scheme as well as over possible oil exploration deals.

Iraq, under U.N. sanctions since its 1990 invasion of Kuwait, was expected to start exporting crude oil in September under a U.N.-brokered deal allowing it to sell $2 billion worth of oil to raise money for essential food and medicines.
The deal has been postponed indefinitely following the U.S. missile strikes on Iraqi military facilities on Tuesday and Wednesday.
Beijing has regarded Taiwan as a rebel province since the end of the Chinese civil war in 1949 and has fiercely blocked the island's attempts to re-enter the United Nations.
Beijing took China's U.N. seat from Taipei in 1971 when the island's exiled Republic of China government was expelled from the world body.
Despite Chinese Petroleum's interest in Iraqi oil, the Taiwan government said it supported the U.S. military action against Iraq.
"The Foreign Ministry thinks the U.S. government's action is justified and appropriate," a ministry spokesman said on Wednesday.
